ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to read and understand Middle English and developed my skills in interpreting, discussing, and analyzing poetry.

This class was the one that convinced me to become an English Major. The emphasis of the class was not only on learning to interpret poetry, but also to appreciate it, something I am deeply grateful for.
Many writing and close reading skills.
I developed a more nuanced appreciation for Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare, Donne, and Milton.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: some of professor's methodology and views are somewhat outdated
The small class size facilitated good discussions. The course could potentially be improved if we had the chance to spend more time with each author/poem.

This class was lovely. Due to the small size, I had a unique opportunity to learn by voicing my opinions and getting feedback immediately rather than only engaging with the professor through papers and comments.
The professor greatly challenged the students to think about and engage with the works of poetry, but there is little freedom in terms of writing papers.

This is an excellent course. Professor Brisman led interesting, insightful class discussions that analyzed each work from the perspective of a different theme for each class. He then tied those themes into our everyday lives. Professor Brisman also offered helpful feedback on essay drafts as well as the final essays, which I appreciated.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, but probably not with this professor
I would recommend this course to students who are interested in becoming more engaged with poetic works.

Yes, but I would not recommend it to very many people. This is not because the class is poor; far from it, the class is so good that any student not looking to deeply appreciate poetry would have a poor experience themselves and lessen the experience of others as well.
I would only recommend it if they're interested in the specific material of this course.

Yes! This was an excellent class. I really enjoyed the class discussions, and Professor Brisman gave helpful feedback on my drafts and essays. Professor Brisman is a wonderful instructor, and I learned a lot about Chaucer and Milton.
